Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer for Use in Research and Research Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Adam Mosey from Lake Superior State University and colleagues R. Marshall Werner, Steven Johnson and Martha Hutchens have acquired a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as the study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the study of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. The results from these NMR studies have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, forensics and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate students via independent student research and traditional academic coursework as well as researchers and students from the Bay Mills Tribal Community College that has a large Native American enrollment.


The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) characterizing the products and mechanism of an enantioselective imadazoline annulation reaction; (b) characterizing Evans-based chiral auxiliary enolates and their resulting aldol reaction products; (c) investigating the anti-microbial properties of 3,4-dihydroquinazolines and (d) exploring the forensic chemistry of compounds, and (e) preparing isotopically-labeled synthetic cannabinoids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award permitted researchers at Lake Superior State University (LSSU) to purchase a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) instrument to assist with their goals of making advances in chemical and biochemical sciences and to integrate modern NMR instrumentation use in college laboratory courses.  The NMR acquired through this award was used to develop new ways of building chemicals with potential medicinal value.  Afterwards, use of the NMR allowed LSSU researchers to determine the structures of new chemicals prepared by these new chemical methods.  Compounds identified using the instrument were evaluated for ability to act on specified biological targets in an effort to determine their suitability as agents to counter various diseases, including antibacterial-resistant infections. Beyond its use for the identification of compounds of medical interest, the NMR has also broadly assisted the LSSU scientific community in a number of diverse areas. Faculty and student researchers at LSSU have used the instrument in numerous classroom and research projects for the structural identification of single compounds or the identification of components of compound mixtures.  Student driven projects have included the identification and quantification of acetaminophen in plasma samples, limonene extracted from orange peel, sucrose in flowers frequented by hummingbirds, ethanol in beer samples, and triglycerides in lake trout tissue samples. Through an ongoing collaboration with Bay Mills Community College, faculty and students from that college have also used the NMR for the identification of wintergreen oil (methyl salicylate) from locally sourced wintergreen plants.
